attributes.title: Future perspective and survival processing
attributes.description: This experiment is designed to test whether verb tense in scenarios influences the survival processing effect (Nairne, Thompson, & Pandeirada, 2007). Survival and nonsurvival scenarios will be written in past or future tense, and a word pleasantness task will be used as a control condition.

q1.value: Future tense perspective and survival processing

q3.value:
The purpose of this project is to test whether memory for survival relevant information is related to future tense perspective.  Studies on adaptive memory have shown that when participants read a scenario that primes them to think about survival (e.g., acquiring crucial resources, avoiding predators), they are better able to remember survival relevant words than when reading a scenario that is relevant to something not directly related to survival, such as packing and moving to a new location, or judging whether a word is pleasant or unpleasant (Nairne, Thompson, & Pandeirada, 2007). For example, participants are asked to read a passage in which they imagine they are stranded in grasslands and must acquire materials to subsist and avoid predators. Next, they read a list of words and rate the degree to which the word is relevant to survival. After a delay period, participants are asked to remember as many words as they can. In a comparison condition participants read a passage about moving to a new home and are asked to rate the survival relevance of the words, and in a control group participants simply rate whether words they see are pleasant or unpleasant. Nairne et al reported that participants remembered more words in the survival condition than in moving and control conditions. Previous work in this area has focused on contemplating survival in the present tense. However, planning for future contingencies is a critical aspect of memory: Literature on human memory shows superior recall for information that is relevant for future, rather than present, needs. The proposed work involves asking participants to contemplate survival in past tense or future tense perspectives, with the prediction that memory will be superior when both survival and future tense perspective are involved. 
 
Nairne, J. S., Thompson, S.R., & Pandeirada, J.N.S. (2007). Adaptive memory: Survival processing enhances retention. Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory and Cognition, 33, 263-273.

q4.value:
A "scenario effect": We predict that memory for words related to any of the four scenarios will be significantly greater than memory for words rated for pleasantness (the control condition). 

A "survival x future tense interaction": We predict that memory will be superior for words rated in the future tense survival scenario in comparison to past tense survival scenario, and also superior to words rated in both past and future tense nonsurvival scenarios.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: This a between subjects design with five groups: survival scenario written in future tense, survival scenario written in past tense, nonsurvival scenario (moving) written future tense, nonsurvival scenario written in past tense, and control (word pleasantness ratings). The experiment will be conducted online using Qualtrics software. Subjects will be randomly assigned to one of the five groups (50 subjects/group). Study materials are attached. Following consent the subjects will read their assigned scenario. Subjects will then be presented with 32 words and will be asked to rate (1-5 scale) each one for its relevance to the scenario they read.  A digit span distraction task will follow. In the last phase subjects will be given 6 minutes to recall as many of the rated words that they can remember.

q9.value: Subjects will be randomly assigned into one of five equally sized blocks. Randomization is handled via qualtrics software.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Subjects will be undergraduate students enrolled in psychology courses at Southern Oregon University. All must be at least 18 years of age to participate. Subjects will be offered a small amount of extra credit for their participation. The timeline will (likely) span January through December 2020 (or until all 215 subjects have completed the study).

q13.value: 215 undergraduate students will be recruited from psychology classes at Southern Oregon University.

q14.value: Based on the software program G*Power. Our goal was .95 power with an alpha error probability set at 0.05, and a .30 effect size. Based on this our target sample size is 215 subjects (43 per group)

question.value: The manipulated variables involve the verb tense in which scenarios are written (past vs future tense) and whether the scenarios refer to a survival scenario (adaptive, evolution relevant) or nonsurvival (moving to a new country). This yields 4 experimental groups. A fifth group is a control group that will evaluate the pleasantness of words.

1) words ratings. We will measure how subjects rate each of the 32 words in relation to their relevance to the 4 scenarios (1=5 scale). Control group will rate the same words for whether they are pleasant or unpleasant. 
2) digit span test performance. Subjects will be asked to memorize 6, 10-item digit spans. Testing for accuracy will be done in multiple choice format. Performance on digit span is not a target variable involved in any hypotheses we are testing. The task is used as a distractor. 
3) memory. Free recall for words previously rated will be measured by asking subjects to type as many words as they can remember in 6 minutes.

ANOVA with pairwise contrasts for all groups will be conducted. Secondary analyses will be done on word item ratings. ANOVA with pairwise comparisons will be done on mean ratings for each of the 5 groups. This analysis will also be done on difference scores for ratings of words remembered minus ratings for words forgotten.

q21.value: alpha is set at 0.05, with correction for multiple comparisons. tests will be two-tailed.

q22.value: If subjects fail to  write down a single word in the memory test at the end of the experiment we will assume they have either discontinued participation or have not followed directions, and will therefore be excluded.

q23.value: The word ratings require a response in order to continue the experiment. If a participant fails to complete the ratings portion, their data are useless, and therefore any word ratings made will be discarded.

q3.value: How do gun owners use their weapons to deal with psychological threat? We hook participants up to a shock generator, then warn provide warnings of whether or not they are at risk of being shocked. For one block of trials, participants hold a metal weight; for another block, they hold the hand of a same-sex friend; for the third block, they hold a realistic prop pistol. By measuring heartrate and self-reported feelings of arousal, pain, and emotional valence, we will be able to see if holding a gun helps gun owners to buffer the anxiety of potential shock, or whether holding the gun sensitizes them to the threats of their environment.

q4.value:
Heartrate data are our primary outcome variable, while self-reports (SAM scales) are our secondary outcome variable

Heartrate (IBI) Predictions
##IBI Predictions:
#Shorter IBIs under threat than under safety.
#Shorter IBIs in the threat/object condition than the threat/handholding condition.

###If guns are general-purpose safety blankets:
#Shorter IBIs for gun owners in the threat/object than in the threat/gun, while non-gun-owners will have shorter IBIs in the threat/gun than the threat/object. Non-gun-owners will have shorter IBIs in threat/gun than will gun-owners

###If guns are orienting mechanisms to threat:
#Shorter IBIs in the threat/gun than threat/object for everyone.

#Gun owners will respond similarly to guns and handholding across all conditions.


###If guns are general-purpose safety blankets:
#Less arousal, less pain, higher valence for guns than objects among gun owners; higher arousal, higher pain, lower valence for guns than objects for non-gun owners

###If guns are orienting mechanisms to threat:
#Higher arousal, less pain, higher valence for guns than objects among gun owners; higher arousal, higher pain, lower valence for guns than objects for non-gun owners

#Gun owners will respond similarly to guns and handholding across all conditions.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: As the study is within-subjects, everyone knows all conditions.

question.value: Three-block within-subjects

q9.value: The order of the blocks (holding a weight, a friend's hand, or the gun) is randomized across participants.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Heartrate/self-report data are still in the process of being cleaned, and all analysis scripts have been developed with a subset of the cleaned data in which the conditions have been reshuffled (so that the relationship between condition and DVs has been broken).

question.value: Participants were recruited from an undergraduate psychology department participant pool.

q13.value: We aimed to recruit roughly 100 participants. At termination of data collection we have 104 participants, but expect that we will lose a few in the data-cleaning process (as their heartrate data may be too messily measured to use).

q14.value: With 100 people, half of whom are gun owners and half not (a reasonable assumption, given the demographics of our sample), with three blocks of measurement, and with g*power default correlation b/n the repeated measures (a default we are willing to accept, given the lack of info about one of our conditions) we would have 80% power to detect a condition by gun-owner interaction of f=0.127 - a relatively small effect, roughy equivalent to a d of .25. In reality, however, since we have multiple measurements within each block, we are likely powered to detect far smaller effect sizes.

q15.value: We terminated data collection at the end of an academic year.

question.value: During a block, participants were assigned to either hold a metal weight, the hand of their friend, or a prop pistol.
See attached.

We scored the BIS/BAS according to Carver & White, 1994; and the MSPSS according to Zimet et al, 1988.
Heartrate data are scored by the attached.

For each primary DV, we use a linear mixed-model, nesting data within participant and dyad.
For IBI, the model is as follows: lmer(IBI ~ Condition*Threat*OwnGun + (Condition*Threat|Dyad/ID), data=shock)


For the SAM scales, the models are as follows: lmer(Score~Condition*OwnGun + (Condition|Dyad.ID/PID), data=sams, subset=SAM=="Arousal") [replace the subset for the other two SAM scales].

Interactions will be decomposed with holm-corrected pariwise tests on the marginal means (see the script in this registration for more details)

q22.value:
We exclude any participant with unusable heartrate data, or any participant that researchers chose to exclude at the end of their experimental session. 

Additionally, we exclude any heartbeats >3*IQR for a given participant.

###If guns are general-purpose safety blankets:
#Less arousal, less pain, higher valence for guns than objects among gun owners; higher arousal, higher pain, lower valence for guns than objects for non-gun owners

###If guns are orienting mechanisms to threat:
#Higher arousal, less pain, higher valence for guns than objects among gun owners; higher arousal, higher pain, lower valence for guns than objects for non-gun owners

registration_responses.q3: How do gun owners use their weapons to deal with psychological threat? We hook participants up to a shock generator, then warn provide warnings of whether or not they are at risk of being shocked. For one block of trials, participants hold a metal weight; for another block, they hold the hand of a same-sex friend; for the third block, they hold a realistic prop pistol. By measuring heartrate and self-reported feelings of arousal, pain, and emotional valence, we will be able to see if holding a gun helps gun owners to buffer the anxiety of potential shock, or whether holding the gun sensitizes them to the threats of their environment.

attributes.title: Isf -attention bias in spider phobia population

q1.value: ISF- Attention bias in non-clinical  fear of spider population

q2.value: Gal Moscona, Einav Gozansky, Hadas Okon-Singer

q3.value:
Individuals with specific phobia have a rapid and excessive response when they are exposed to their phobic stimulus. Previous studies have found that attentional biases play a pivotal role in preservation or even etiology for spider phobia.
In the current study, we will employ a modified perceptual load task (Okon-Singer et al., 2007, 2014) to further investigate attentional biases in a population with spider high and low fear groups. Specifically, how unattended fear-related non-social (i.e., spiders) and social (i.e., angry faces) stimuli effect performance among low and high spider fear groups.

q4.value:
1) Task load will influence performance, such that high load will result in longer reaction time (RT) and lower accuracy compared to low load.
2) Participants with high spider will show a difference between spider and bird distractors only in the low load condition.
3) Due to the high frequency of faces in our lives, all participants are expected to show a difference between angry and neutral faces in the low load condition.
4) A positive correlation between FSQ level and the difference in RT in spider vs. bird trials in low load.
5) A positive correlation between LSAS level and the difference in RT in angry vs. neutral face trials in low load.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The experiment will be conducted using a mixed design. The study will include one between-subjects factor with two levels (high and low fear of spider, non-clinical population). There will be 3 within-subjects factors (load: high and low; valence: negative and neutral; type of threat: social and non-social). 
The study will be conducted in a counterbalanced block design, (fear related and social negative condition). In each block, valence and load will be randomly presented.

q9.value: In each block the stimuli will appear randomly using E-prime v3.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited using SONA, a system for University students. At the end of the experiment, participants will fill up the FSQ questionnaire. If the randomized collection will not contain enough participants for one of the groups (either high or low fear of spiders), we will publish the experiment in social media and recruit only high fear using the FSQ questionnaire. Participants will be paid 40 shekels or receive 1 credit point for an hour experiment.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 50 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 70 assuming that not all participants will complete the total task or accuracy level will not reach 50%.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .8 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value: We will manipulate the following factors: (1) cognitive load- two levels: low (1 letter), high (6 letters); (2) Type of threat: social (faces) and non-social (spiders/birds); (3) Picture valence- two levels: neutral (birds/neutral faces) and negative (spiders/angry faces).

We will measure fear of spider as a predictor using FSQ questionnaire.
The outcome variables will be reaction time and accuracy percentage.
We will also collect data regrading anxiety - LSAS for social anxiety and STAI-T and STAI-S questionnaires.

We will use a standard 4-WAY ANOVA to analyze the data. For the ANOVA, we will compute for each subject the average RT for each of the conditions. We will also average the RT in each condition for each group (high/low fear). 
In addition, we will compute two interference indices for each load separately: the average of neutral RT - average social and the average of neutral RT - fear related conditions.
we will also compute the average accuracy in the same way.

We will use a  2 X 2 X 2 X 2 repeated -measures ANOVA (RMANOVA) with all factors to analyze our results. 
In addition, two simple regression analyses will be employed to examine the correlation between FSQ level and the difference in RT in spider vs. bird trials in the low load condition, as well as the level of LSAS and the difference in RT in angry vs. neutral face trials in the low load condition.

q22.value:
Participants that did not reach 50% accuracy will not be included. 
RT analysis will be done only for correct answers and will exclude trials that are below or above 2.5 standard deviations.

q23.value: We will exclude participants who did not finish the experiment or did fill out the FSQ.

attributes.title: Person-Environment Fit in the context of sports and its relation to affect, sport and life satisfaction

q1.value: Person-Environment Fit in the context of sports and its relation to affect, sport and life satisfaction

q2.value: Sophia Terwiel, Maike Luhmann, John Rauthmann, Sarah Kritzler

q3.value:
Physical activity and sport participation are positively related to physical and mental health (Chekroud et al., 2018; Curtis et al., 2017; Schuch et al., 2016) as well as to happiness and well-being (Zhang & Chen, 2019). Various mechanisms are assumed to mediate this association, ranging from biological explanations to social integration theories (e.g., Netz, Wu, Becker, & Tenenbaum, 2005). In our study, we propose that another mechanism – person-environment fit (here: how well an athlete fits into the specific characteristics of the environment of her/his sport) – might explain the association between sport and well-being. 
Person-environment fit refers to the congruence between characteristics of an individual (e.g., personality traits) and characteristics of the environment (e.g., job demands; Kristof-Brown & Guay, 2011). In organizational contexts, a fit between an employee’s personality traits or abilities and job demands has been found to be associated with higher job satisfaction and well-being (Hardin & Donaldson III, 2014). In the context of sports, the interplay between a person and environmental factors has so far been insufficiently investigated (Allen & Laborde, 2014). However, it has been found that personality traits, especially the Big Five, differ on average in meaningful ways between athletes of different types of sports (Allen, Greenlees, & Jones, 2011). Thus, supplemental fit, defined as having a personality trait profile resembling that of other people surrounding in a given context (Furr, 2008; Muchinsky & Monahan, 1987), could be a potential mechanism driving the feeling of belonging in the context of sport (Allen & Laborde, 2014). Investigating similarity fit or fit in general can be done in either a variable-oriented or a profile-oriented way. In the present study, we will focus on a variable-oriented approach. We examine to what extent the fit between athletes’ individual personality traits and the typical personality traits of other athletes in the same sports discipline is associated with the athletes’ satisfaction with the sport and general well-being for each of the Big Five domains.

q4.value:
We expect congruence between the typical level (see Study Design: Dataset 1) and the individual athletes’ level (see Study Design: Dataset 2) on the Big Five personality trait domains to be associated with higher levels of sport satisfaction, life satisfaction, and mood (OR higher positive affect and lower levels of negative affect; see below for this distinction). We, moreover, expect that there will be main effects of personality traits on sport satisfaction, life satisfaction, and mood (OR higher positive affect and lower levels of negative affect). Therefore, we assume to identify broad congruence effects. 

To identify congruence, we estimate response surface analyses (RSA) models (see below for details) and follow the definition by (see Humberg, Nestler, & Back, 2018) who state that broad congruence is present if the RSA parameters meet the following conditions : (1) a1 > 0 or a1 < 0 and a2 = 0; (2) the line of incongruence (LOIC) for the fixed effects is U-shaped with a maximum above the LOC, which is given when a4 < 0 and a3 = 0; and (3) the LOC for the fixed effects equals the first principal axis (FPA) of the fixed effects, which is given when a5 = 0. As person-environment fit has been insufficiently investigated in the sport context, we have no detailed hypotheses concerning the fit effects of the different combination of Big Five pairs (e.g. typical Extraversion – individual Extraversion).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In Study 1, N = 5,072 athletes of 103 sports rated either the typical male or female athlete’s personality of their main sport for the Big Five domains on the items of the BFI-2-S (German version: Danner et al., 2016; Soto & John, 2017). The ratings for each sport were aggregated separately for males and females to create a database of typical athletes’ personality profiles. 
In Study 2, individual personality profiles of N = 4,912 athletes’ of 103 sports were collected using again the BFI-2-S (German version: Danner et al., 2016; Soto & John, 2017). Sport satisfaction was measured using an adapted version (Baudin, Aluja, Rolland, & Blanch, 2011) of the Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS; Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985; German version: Glaesmer, Grande, & Roth, 2011). Life satisfaction was measured using the SWLS. Affective well-being/Mood was measured using the Scale of Positive and Negative Experience (SPANE; Diener et al., 2014; German version: Rahm, Heise, & Schuldt, 2017).

q11.value: Most variables (life satisfaction, mood, sport satisfaction) have not yet been analyzed at all. The personality variables have been used to determine the final sample size in Dataset 1, as only sports with good interrater agreement (i.e. ICCs > .6) have been included in the dataset.

Dataset 1: see https://osf.io/m9nc5/ 
BFI-2-S (German version: Danner et al., 2016; Soto & John, 2017) 
Participants are asked to complete the BFI-2-S twice: (1) with respect to the ideal athlete of one’s main sport, (2) with respect to the prototypic/typical athlete of one’s main sport. 
- Participants are randomly assigned to describing either male or female athletes
- Instruction were adapted to fit the purpose of the study: 
o ” On the following pages, we invite you to answer questionnaires concerning the personality of the typical or the ideal athlete of your sport. What exactly does that mean? To characterize a typical athlete, imagine what kind of people you meet when going to training or competitions and what you would state to be typical for e.g. a soccer player. To characterize an ideal athlete, imagine which personality traits an ideal athlete needs to perform as well as possible in a competition or to compete at the highest competitive level.” 
- Instruction for questionnaire concerning a typical male athlete 
o To characterize a typical male athlete, imagine what kind of men you meet when going to training or competitions and what you would state to be typical for e.g. a male soccer player. On the next page are a number of characteristics that may or may not apply to a typical male athlete of the sport x}. For example, do you agree that this athlete is someone who likes to spend time with others? 

- To ensure that the instructions were read and understood, participants were asked after completing each BFI-2-S to indicate for which athlete (typical male, typical female, ideal male, ideal female) they had made their assessments. 


Dataset 2: 
- Individual values Big Five: BFI-2-S (German version: Danner et al., 2016; Soto & John, 2017) 
- Life satisfaction: Satisfaction With Life Scale (Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985; German version: Glaesmer, Grande, Braehler, & Roth, 2011)
- Sport satisfaction: adapted version (see Baudin, Aluja, Rolland, & Blanch, 2011). of the Satisfaction With Life Scale (Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985; German version: Glaesmer, Grande, Braehler, & Roth, 2011)
- Mood: Scale of Positive and Negative Experience (SPANE; Diener et al., 2010; German version: Rahm, Heise, & Schuldt, 2017) 
o We will calculate the correlation between the two scales of positive and negative affect on an individual base. If the correlation coefficient is > .7, the two scales will be combined into the scale “mood”. Given a correlation coefficient > .7, we can assume that the calculation of polynomial and response surface analyses for positive and negative affect separately will not yield further information.
- scale scores for the BFI-2-S, the SWLS, the sport SWLS and the SPANE will be calculated (see attached Codebook)

Considering the nested structure of the data (athletes nested within sports), the data will be analyzed using multilevel polynomial regression analyses (Nestler, Humberg, & Schönbrodt, 2019) with response surface analyses (RSA). RSA is a tool to test congruence hypotheses like the one given in the present study and allows for a more precise identification and direct investigation of the associations of interest compared to other types of fit analyses (Barranti, Carlson, & Côté, 2017). The analyses will be performed using the R package RSA (Schönbrodt & Humberg, 2018) as well as additional functions considering the multilevel structure by Nestler and colleagues (2019). Polynomial regressions and response surface analyses will be conducted across all 103 sports and both genders for each pair of the Big Five domains (Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness and Neuroticism) and for all outcomes (sport satisfaction, life satisfaction, mood OR positive affect & negative affect) separately, resulting in either 15 or 20 different (depending whether we combine the mood scale or calculate results for positive and negative affect separately)  fit analyses and RSA graphs (for an example, see Figure 1). 
Whenever possible, random slope models will be estimated. If more than 10% of the random slopes models do not converge (either 1 or 2 models), we will instead estimate random intercept models for all planned analyses.

q20.value:
The individual and typical Big Five traits (Openness to Experience, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness and Neuroticism) will be centered on the scale midpoint or the group mean midpoint of both scales. 
To choose the optimal centering method, we will examine the distribution of the individual scores of the Big Five traits for each sport. If the midpoint of the given group is not included in the interval between plus and minus one standard deviation of the given distributions for more than 5% of the sports, we will center the variables on the mean of the group means of both scales. Otherwise, we will center on the scale midpoints. The chosen centering method will be performed in the same way for all included analyses after a decision has been made based on the stated criteria.

registration_responses.q1: Person-Environment Fit in the context of sports and its relation to affect, sport and life satisfaction
registration_responses.q2: Sophia Terwiel, Maike Luhmann, John Rauthmann, Sarah Kritzler
registration_responses.q3:
Physical activity and sport participation are positively related to physical and mental health (Chekroud et al., 2018; Curtis et al., 2017; Schuch et al., 2016) as well as to happiness and well-being (Zhang & Chen, 2019). Various mechanisms are assumed to mediate this association, ranging from biological explanations to social integration theories (e.g., Netz, Wu, Becker, & Tenenbaum, 2005). In our study, we propose that another mechanism – person-environment fit (here: how well an athlete fits into the specific characteristics of the environment of her/his sport) – might explain the association between sport and well-being. 
Person-environment fit refers to the congruence between characteristics of an individual (e.g., personality traits) and characteristics of the environment (e.g., job demands; Kristof-Brown & Guay, 2011). In organizational contexts, a fit between an employee’s personality traits or abilities and job demands has been found to be associated with higher job satisfaction and well-being (Hardin & Donaldson III, 2014). In the context of sports, the interplay between a person and environmental factors has so far been insufficiently investigated (Allen & Laborde, 2014). However, it has been found that personality traits, especially the Big Five, differ on average in meaningful ways between athletes of different types of sports (Allen, Greenlees, & Jones, 2011). Thus, supplemental fit, defined as having a personality trait profile resembling that of other people surrounding in a given context (Furr, 2008; Muchinsky & Monahan, 1987), could be a potential mechanism driving the feeling of belonging in the context of sport (Allen & Laborde, 2014). Investigating similarity fit or fit in general can be done in either a variable-oriented or a profile-oriented way. In the present study, we will focus on a variable-oriented approach. We examine to what extent the fit between athletes’ individual personality traits and the typical personality traits of other athletes in the same sports discipline is associated with the athletes’ satisfaction with the sport and general well-being for each of the Big Five domains.
registration_responses.q4:
We expect congruence between the typical level (see Study Design: Dataset 1) and the individual athletes’ level (see Study Design: Dataset 2) on the Big Five personality trait domains to be associated with higher levels of sport satisfaction, life satisfaction, and mood (OR higher positive affect and lower levels of negative affect; see below for this distinction). We, moreover, expect that there will be main effects of personality traits on sport satisfaction, life satisfaction, and mood (OR higher positive affect and lower levels of negative affect). Therefore, we assume to identify broad congruence effects. 

To identify congruence, we estimate response surface analyses (RSA) models (see below for details) and follow the definition by (see Humberg, Nestler, & Back, 2018) who state that broad congruence is present if the RSA parameters meet the following conditions : (1) a1 > 0 or a1 < 0 and a2 = 0; (2) the line of incongruence (LOIC) for the fixed effects is U-shaped with a maximum above the LOC, which is given when a4 < 0 and a3 = 0; and (3) the LOC for the fixed effects equals the first principal axis (FPA) of the fixed effects, which is given when a5 = 0. As person-environment fit has been insufficiently investigated in the sport context, we have no detailed hypotheses concerning the fit effects of the different combination of Big Five pairs (e.g. typical Extraversion – individual Extraversion).

registration_responses.q8.question:
In Study 1, N = 5,072 athletes of 103 sports rated either the typical male or female athlete’s personality of their main sport for the Big Five domains on the items of the BFI-2-S (German version: Danner et al., 2016; Soto & John, 2017). The ratings for each sport were aggregated separately for males and females to create a database of typical athletes’ personality profiles. 
In Study 2, individual personality profiles of N = 4,912 athletes’ of 103 sports were collected using again the BFI-2-S (German version: Danner et al., 2016; Soto & John, 2017). Sport satisfaction was measured using an adapted version (Baudin, Aluja, Rolland, & Blanch, 2011) of the Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS; Diener, Emmons, Larsen, & Griffin, 1985; German version: Glaesmer, Grande, & Roth, 2011). Life satisfaction was measured using the SWLS. Affective well-being/Mood was measured using the Scale of Positive and Negative Experience (SPANE; Diener et al., 2014; German version: Rahm, Heise, & Schuldt, 2017).

attributes.title: The impact of major depression on the placement of event boundaries
attributes.description: This project aims to explore differences in event segmentation between healthy and depressed indiviudals.

q2.value: Caitlin Hitchcock, Chase Antonacci, Aya Ben-Yakov, Edwin Dalmaijer

q3.value: The objective of this study is to explore the role of event segmentation in depression. Though depression is often associated with systematic abnormalities in autobiographical memory, it remains unknown whether event segmentation – a core feature of memory encoding – plays a role in depressive cognition. We will explore whether patterns of event boundary placement differ between depressed and healthy individuals during the perception of naturalistic events (i.e., film clips). Enhancing models of event segmentation may improve our understanding of the core cognitive processes that underlie depression and help to guide future treatment strategies.

q4.value:
1)	Depressive symptoms will be associated with different patterns of event boundary placement.
a.	Segmentation agreement scores will be lower in the depressed group relative to the healthy control group. 
b.	The depressed group will demonstrate a lower number of event boundaries relative to the healthy control group.  
2)	Depressive symptoms will be associated with systematic differences in boundary placement in response to independently identified emotional events during film clips. 
a.	Depressed individuals will identify a higher proportion of emotion-related boundaries relative to controls.  
b.	Within the depressed group, individuals will be more likely to place boundaries proximal to positive rather than negative events.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Group membership will be coded such that the individual who analyzes the data is blind to participants’ depressive status.

question.value: In this quasi-experiment, participants will be asked to watch several film clips and indicate a boundary between two meaningful events using a key press (adapted from Zacks et al., 2010).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Collection of behavioral data to begin in early 2020, post registration. Our potential exploratory analysis will use neuroimaging data from the Cambridge Centre for Ageing and Neuroscience (CamCAN) study (https://www.cam-can.org) and StudyForrest (http://studyforrest.org). Though these data have been analyzed for various research questions, no analyses have been performed to explore differences in event segmentation between depressed and healthy individuals. Additionally, we will use data from the StudyForrest Project in which three independent raters identified emotional events in the film Forrest Gump (Labs et al., 2015). These data serve as a tool for indexing events identified by participants and will not be part of the data analyzed to address our research question

question.value:
Healthy participants with no previous history of psychiatric disturbance are to be recruited from the MRC Cognition and Brain Sciences Unit panel of research volunteers. The panel is comprised of approximately 4000 individuals who have responded to print and online advertisements requesting volunteers to participate in research at the MRC Cognition and Brain Sciences Unit. Depressed participants are to be recruited from the MRC Cognition and Brain Sciences Unit panel of research volunteers who have a history of mental health disorders. The panel is comprised of approximately 500 individuals who have responded to print and online advertisements requesting volunteers to participate in research at the MRC Cognition and Brain Sciences Unit. Current experience of a Major Depressive Episode will be determined using the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM Disorders- Fifth edition. 
For both groups, exclusion criteria are intellectual disability, traumatic brain injury, neurological disorder, or current substance/alcohol use disorder. For healthy control participants, exclusion criteria also comprise presence of a current or prior diagnosis of a DSM disorder and/or score of 13 or more (above the cut-off for the mild range) on the Beck Depression Inventory II (BDI-II; Beck et al., 1996). 
All testing sessions are to be held in a quiet testing room at the MRC Cognition and Brain Sciences Unit, following the provision of written informed consent. Participants will be reimbursed at a rate of £6 per hour for their time, plus travel expenses.

q13.value: Power calculation (two-tailed, alpha = .05) using the effect of PTSD symptom severity on segmentation agreement (d=.54) observed by Eisenberg et al. (2016) indicated that 55 participants in each group would provide 80% power.

question.value:
Primary outcomes: number and position of identified event boundaries within film clips; segmentation agreement scores within each group. 
Covariates of interest: age, working memory using Digit Span Test, executive fluency using the Verbal Fluency Task, and autobiographical memory using the Autobiographical Memory Test.
Symptom measures: Ruminative Response Scale, Beck Depression Inventory-II

Film clips will be split into 1-second bins. This will allow us to determine if an event boundary is placed in a bin containing an emotional event, or in a bin that immediately precedes or follows an emotional event. Segmentation agreement scores will be calculated by group for each film (Bang! You’re Dead and Forrest Gump) independently. Segmentation agreement is a measure of how well each participant’s segmentation agreed with that of the group (Zacks et al., 2006). For each movie, we will compute the point-biserial correlation between each individual’s segmentation and the proportion of participants that segmented at each 1-second bin. The larger the correlation, the better the agreement with the group.

Hypothesis 1 and 2 will be analyses using a series of independent samples t-tests comparing depressed and healthy control participants on segmentation agreement scores, the number of boundaries, and the proportion of emotion-based boundaries identified. Any between-groups differences in the covariates of interest will be controlled for in analysis. Bonferroni correction will be applied to control for multiple comparisons.

q21.value: Two-tailed analyses are planned. Null hypothesis testing will be completed with alpha = .05.

q22.value: Any participants failing to index any event boundaries will be excluded.

q24.value:
Previous research has suggested that the hippocampus modulates event segmentation processes, demonstrating both sensitivity and selectivity to event boundaries (Ben-Yakov & Henson, 2018). However, it remains unclear whether event type (e.g., emotionally positive versus negative) modulates hippocampal activity in this context. If our primary analyses suggest behavioral-level differences in segmentation between event types, we will then explore whether these behavioral differences are associated with differences in neuroimaging data taken from the Cambridge Centre for Ageing and Neuroscience (CamCAN) study (https://www.cam-can.org) and StudyForrest (http://studyforrest.org). 
Additionally, we may implement a participant feedback section wherein, after watching and segmenting film clips, participants will be shown a few seconds of video before and after they placed boundaries and be asked to provide a typed explanation regarding what features of the film motivated them to indicate an event boundary. These data will be used to examine reliability between participants’ self-reported perception of emotional events and the emotional events identified by Labs et al., 2015.

Segmentation agreement scores will be calculated by group for each film (Bang! You’re Dead and Forrest Gump) independently. Segmentation agreement is a measure of how well each participant’s segmentation agreed with that of the group (Zacks et al., 2006). For each movie, we will compute the point-biserial correlation between each individual’s segmentation and the proportion of participants that segmented at each 1-second bin. The larger the correlation, the better the agreement with the group.
registration_responses.q19.question: Hypothesis 1 and 2 will be analyses using a series of independent samples t-tests comparing depressed and healthy control participants on segmentation agreement scores, the number of boundaries, and the proportion of emotion-based boundaries identified. Any between-groups differences in the covariates of interest will be controlled for in analysis. Bonferroni correction will be applied to control for multiple comparisons.

sample.value:
The planned sample size is N=102 participants (51 per condition). 

power analysis based on the smallest effect size of interest was used. Accordingly, small to medium effect is chosen as this effect is feasible and of practical importance. 
For the same parameters: alpha error probability .05; Power 0.80. Test family: t-test; Statistical test: Means: Difference between two independent means (two groups). Type of power analysis (a priori: Compute required sample size – given alpha; power and effect size). Tail: one (as the specific direction is hypothesized) and medium effect size (Cohen´s d=.50); N=102 participants (51 per condition) is necessary.

analyses.value:
For the test of the main hypothesis, the T-test for two independent groups will be used. P-value will be set to conventional .05; One side hypothesis will be used. Except for frequentists approach, Bayes factor will be used with interpretational benchmarks according to Wagenmakers et al. (2018). Moreover, moderation analysis with time perstive and self-regulation. 

For further exploratory analysis, Manova for Small, Medium and Large K with Anova as post hoc test will be used. P-value correction will be used. 

For the secondary analysis, simple moderation analysis will be used (Hayes, 2017; Hayes & Rockwood, 2016). The results will be considered significant if 95% confidence interval will not include zero. Moderators that will be examined: self-control and time perspective.

dependent.value:
Overal K score computed according to Kaplan et. al (2016). 

Additionally, small, medium, large K will be analyzed as well.

conditions.value: Participants will be assigned to why (high construal) vs. how (low construal) conditions (Construal level manipulation)

hypothesis.value:
Participants in why a group (high construal) will prefer larger delayed rewrds in comaprisson to participants in how (low construal).

The relationship between construal level manipulation and delay-discounting will be moderated by time perspective (fatalistic and hedonistic present, and future positive) and self-regulation (impulsivity control).

attributes.title: Effectiveness of N95 Respirators vs Medical Masks for Influenza Prevention Among Health Care Workers

summary.value: The outbreak of the 2019-nCoV have triggered global discussion again on the controversial recommendations about the effectiveness of N95 filtering facepiece respirators (N95 respirators) versus surgical masks in preventing acute respiratory infection. As the coronavirus epidemic gradually spread between nations and regions, the panic that led to a shortage of face masks has driven another socioeconomical issue. Acute respiratory infections, including COVID-19, are primarily transmitted by contact and droplet routes; consequently, protection of the respiratory tract became an important issue. Former guideline published by Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) suggests the superiority of N95 respirators over surgical masks for preventing acute respiratory infections. Meanwhile, randomized controlled trials (RCTs), observational studies, systematic reviews, and meta-analyses comparing N95 respirators and surgical masks have not shown conclusive results. With a recently published RCT indicating no significant difference in the incidence of laboratory-confirmed influenza between N95 respirators and surgical masks, there may be new evidence in the debate. Thus, this systemic review and meta-analysis of RCTs aimed to clarify the effectiveness of N95 respirators versus surgical masks in preventing acute respiratory infection.
